ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

PSLE RESULTS FOR 1981
(Schools with highest rate of improvement)


    1. Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education which five primary schools have shown the highest rate of improvement in their PSLE results for 1981 as compared to the results for 1980 and whether he knows the reasons for their good performance.

     The Minister of State of Education (Dr Tay Eng Soon) (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Sir, our records show that the following five primary schools have registered the highest rate of improvement in their PSLE results not just from 1980 to 1981 but over the past three years. They are:

    1. Elling North Primary School

    2. Kallang Primary School

    3. Cantonment Primary School

    4. Kembangan Primary School

    5. Bukit Ho Swee East Primary School. In this analysis (Cols. 347 - 348) the Ministry omitted those schools which have only one or two PSLE classes as being unrepresentative.
analysis - PRIMARY SCHOOL LEAVING EXAMINATION (Cols. 347 - 348)


    Several factors can account for the good performance of these schools. The key factor appears to be the principal. The principals of these schools, and I may add also of other good schools, are men and women who have the leadership and professional vision to initiate special projects such as reading, mathematics or remedial teaching. They are

Column: 290

able to convince their teachers that such hard work can bear fruit.

    For example, the principal of Elling North launched a crash programme in English in 1979. Children were tested to see if they had acquired certain skills expected at each level. Remedial or corrective measures were provided for pupils who were discovered to be weak. In Kallang Primary School the principal initiated a creative English programme which has achieved remarkable results with children from poor home environments. The principal of Cantonment Primary School introduced special methods to teach Mathematics which improved the Mathematics results in the school significantly.

    As for Kembangan Primary School, the hon. Member for Kampong Kembangan is familiar with the Partners in Education Project which involves the teachers, parents and community leaders. The attention which the school has received through the project has motivated teachers and pupils to improve their performance.

    Committed and motivated teachers can do much to help the pupils in their schools. In the five schools that I have mentioned, the yearly improvements in PSLE results are due to the efforts and dedication of both their principals and teachers. The same can be said of schools which have year after year obtained consistently good results.

     Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi (Kampong Kembangan): Sir, noting the important role of school principals in their effort to upgrade the school performance in PSLE in so far as the primary schools are concerned, would the Hon. Minister of State inform the House whether the Ministry has further plans to ensure that the school principals will acquire better skills in management and also will have a wider scope of ingenuity and initiative in searching for projects which can help to upgrade the performance of schools?

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Sir, the answer to the question is "Yes". My Ministry is looking into the possibility of organizing courses which will help school administrators, including principals, in their duties and in improving their leadership in the running of schools.

PRIMARY SCHOOL FOR RADIN MAS/TELOK BLANGAH AREA
(Building of)


    2. Mr M.K.A. Jabbar asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education whether his Ministry has any plan to build a new primary school in the Radin Mas/Telok Blangah area as there are not enough places for all the children in the area seeking admission to Primary I classes in the Blangah Rise Primary School.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Sir, there are three primary schools and two full schools in the Radin Mas Constituency. In the Telok Blangah Constituency, there is only one primary school, Kampong Jagoh School. This school, however, will be closed in January 1982. The buildings will be demolished, as it is an old school, and the site redeveloped into a new 1980 standard primary school. The new school is expected to be completed in mid-1984.

    One new primary school at Bukit Purmei in Radin Mas Constituency will be completed in September, 1983. Soil investigation of the site has been completed and piling tenders are being prepared. In the Telok Blangah Constituency, two new primary schools, in addition to the redevelopment of Kampong Jagoh School, will also be built. Soil investigation of the site for the first school at Telok Blangah Drive has just been completed. The school is expected to be completed in mid-1983. Plans for the second school at Telok Blangah Road are now with the Planning authorities. The expected completion date is December 1983.

    When all the new schools are completed by 1984, there would be enough places for children in the Radin Mas/Telok Blangah areas. Meanwhile, children in the area can join nearby schools in the adjoining constituencies such as Telok Blangah Primary School at Kampong Bahru Road, Silat School I and Silat School II at Jalan Bukit Merah, These schools still have places for more Primary I pupils after the registration exercise in the middle of this year.

BUILDING OF SCHOOLS AT ALJUNIED ROAD/ALJUNIED WAY AND GEYLANG SERAI


    3. Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education (a) what is the progress of the construction of the secondary school at Aljunied Road/Aljunied Way and the expected date of completion of the school; and (b) whether there is any plan to construct a primary school in the Geylang Serai Constituency.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Sir, piling work is in progress for the building of the secondary school at Aljunied Road/Aljunied Way and the school is scheduled for completion in November 1983. On the same site, a primary school will also be built. Plans for this primary school are being prepared now and construction work will start in September 1982. The school is expected to be completed in June 1984.

    In addition, two primary and one secondary schools are being planned in the Geylang area, which covers the Geylang Serai constituency. Sites for the three schools have not been decided but the schools are targetted for completion in 1985 or 1986.

CENTRAL PROVIDENT FUND SAVINGS
(Exemption from estate duty)


    4. Dr Ow Chin Hock asked the Minister for Finance, in view of the facility to use Central Provident Fund savings to purchase property which may enjoy exemption from estate duty up to the value of $600,000, if he will grant similar exemption to CPF balances of up to $600,000 upon the death of a contributor who does not own property.

     The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer to the Member's question is, simply, no.

    The exemption from estate duty for residential property is to encourage home ownership and to ensure that families do not lose their homes on the death of the bread-winner on account of estate duties. For this

Column: 293

reason the exemption limit was revised to $600,000 this year to take into account the higher prices of properties.

    The Government's intention is best carried out by exemption applied direct to property owned, i.e. to property actually, and not notionally, owned. I do not therefore propose to grant exemption from duty on CPF savings, or indeed other savings, whether in the Post Office Savings Bank, in banks or other savings institutions, of up to $600,000 on an estate of a deceased who does not own any residential property. The exemption ceiling in respect of such an estate will remain for the present at $100,000.

PREFERENTIAL ADDITIONAL
REGISTRATION FEE SCHEME
(Extension to motor cars up to 15 years old)


    5. Dr Ow Chin Hock asked the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour, in view of the introduction of compulsory inspection of motor vehicles as from 1st January, 1982, if he will extend the Preferential Additional Registration Fee Scheme to motor cars up to 15 years old and, if not, why not.

     The Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour (Mr Ong Teng Cheong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Preferential Additional Registration Fee (PARF) was introduced on 31st December 1975, primarily to encourage car owners to replace their cars early, that is, before they are more than 10 years old. A surcharge on road tax was also levied on cars which were over 10 years old. These two measures were introduced so that we could have a younger car population and thereby improve the level of roadworthiness of cars and, therefore, road

Column: 294

safety in Singapore. This would also cut down air and noise pollution from cars.

    With the introduction of compulsory car inspection next year, it could be argued that there is no longer any need to encourage car owners to replace their cars early by continuing with the PARF incentive or surcharge disincentive. The Government has already decided that the surcharge on old cars will be abolished with effect from 1st January 1982. The question is: what do we do with the PARF? Some have argued that the 10-year age limit for cars to qualify for PARF should be abolished or increased to 15 years as proposed by the hon. Member. Others take this argument to its logical conclusion by suggesting that there should be no age limit, in which case the PARF should also be abolished.

    I think we ought to evaluate the results of vehicle inspections over a period of time before deciding whether or not to change present policy.

    Therefore, for the moment I do not intend to change the 10-year limit for PARF.

     Mr Ho See Beng (Khe Bong): Mr Speaker, Sir, in place of a similar question* I have filed, I just want to ask a supplementary question. Since the Minister says that he will not give PARF concessions at the moment, how does he expect the car population to be reduced on the road?

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am afraid the Member missed my point. I did not say that we are not going to give Preferential Additional Registration Fee incentives. I am saying that we will keep it for the time being until we have been given a chance to study the results of car inspections over a period of time before deciding what to do with the PARF, So for the time being, we will retain the PARF scheme with the 10-year age limit. There is no change for the time being.

EAST COAST PARKWAY

    7. Mr Rohan bin Kamis asked the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour when the revised speed limit will be implemented along the recently completed East Coast Parkway.

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the speed limit for the East Coast Parkway and the two major stretches of the Pan Island Expressway will be raised from 70 km per hour to 80 km per hour with effect from 3 1st December, 1981.

TAXI DRIVER'S LICENCE
(Priority for test to applicant on
compassionate grounds)


    8. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour whether the Registrar of Vehicles will consider granting priority for a test to an applicant for a taxi driver's licence on compassionate grounds.

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Registrar of Vehicles will consider granting priority for a test to an applicant for a taxi driver's licence on compassionate grounds, but only for exceptional cases. Over a short period of two weeks the Registry of Vehicles received about 22,000 applications for taxi driver's licence when it invited applications in May this year. Only applicants who fulfilled the prerequisite conditions were selected to attend a training course and take the test. Many applicants have claimed to be unemployed or in financial hardship and have asked to be given priority to sit for the test. Much as the Registry of Vehicles would like to help, it is not possible to grant priority to so many of them. Therefore, only exceptional cases will be considered.

COMPULSORY INSURANCE FOR
SHIP'S CREW


    9. Mr Lim Boon Heng asked the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour, in view of the environmental risks peculiar to seafarers, if he will consider making it compulsory for shipowners and/or operators of ships (i) to insure the crew in respect of accidental bodily injury or death occurring on board the ship; and (ii) to compensate the crew for loss of personal effects arising from loss of vessel or fire on board the ship.

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Mr Speaker, Sir, at present, it is already made compulsory for shipowners to insure the crew in respect of accidental bodily injury or death occurring on board ships. All seafarers earning up to $1,250 per month are entitled to compensation under the Workmen's Compensation Act. However, those seafarers who are performing manual work are still covered by the Act even though they may be earning more

Column: 297

than $1,250 per month. Finally, there is a class of seafarers who earn more than $1,250 p.m. and who are not doing manual work, such as shipmasters, engineers and other officers who are not entitled to compensation under the Act. For these sea-farers, the Marine Department has, since August this year, required shipowners to take out insurance coverage separately for them. This is done by incorporating it as a clause in the crew agreements signed between ship-owners and their employees in respect of Singapore flag ships. Such crew agreements have to be approved by the Marine Department.

    As regards compensation to crew for loss of personal effects arising from loss of vessel or fire on board ships, the Marine Department has also required shipowners to take out insurance coverage against possible loss in the crew agreements.

    So far these arrangements have been found satisfactory.

UNEMPLOYMENT AND RETRENCHMENT


    10. Mr Goh Chee Wee asked the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour if the Ministry of Labour is monitoring closely the situation of unemployment and the problems of retrenchment in Singapore; what steps the Ministry will take to help retrenched workers to find alternative employment and to acquire new skills; what measures will be introduced to encourage companies to employ retrenched workers; and what is the projection of the unemployment rate in Singapore for the next two years.

     The Minister of State for Labour (Dr Wong Kwei Cheong) (for the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, my Ministry has been monitoring closely the unemployment and retrenchment situation. A system for monitoring retrenchment and placement of retrenched workers in alternative employment has been in existence since 1974.

Column: 298



    Our monitoring shows that retrenchment is not a problem. For the period January to November 1981, 109 companies reported a retrenchment of about 7,900 workers. The Member for Boon Lay may wish to know that workers at Rollei accounted for about 40% of this number. In a tight labour market most of the retrenched workers found alternative employment without difficulty. Retrenched workers who need training can apply for training courses offered by joint Government-industry training centres and the VITB.

    The measures for monitoring, placement and training of retrenched workers are adequate to deal with the present situation. Should the need arise in the future, new measures will be considered.

    In June 1981, the unemployment rate was 2.9% as compared with 3.0% in June 1980. Based on this trend, we do not anticipate any significant change in the unemployment situation over the next two years.

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD
(Improvement of services)


    11. Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon asked the Minister for National Development whether he is aware that the standard of service provided by the Housing and Development Board has not improved although the conservancy charges have increased, and what steps the HDB is taking to improve the service.

     The Minister of State for National Development (Mr Lee Yock Suan) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the service and conservancy charges that the Housing and Development Board collects from residents are used to pay the salaries and wages of cleansing and maintenance staff, water and electricity charges for lifts and other common areas, domestic refuse collection fees, maintenance and repair of lifts, water tanks and other amenities as well as general repairs and redecoration. The charges collected are insufficient to pay for the costs to HDB of providing these services. In spite of this, the

Column: 299

quality of services taken as a whole has improved although the hon. Member for Tiong Bahru may not be aware of it. The overall cleanliness could improve further if the residents would give HDB their full cooperation and behave responsibly.

    The service and conservancy charges remained static for many years until the first increase in July 1974. After that, there were no further increases until 1980, six years later. Between 1974 and 1980, the cost for the-provision of conservancy services in HDB estates increased tremendously. The main cost items are labour costs, utility charges and the costs of repairs, maintenance and redecoration. We should compare these costs on a per unit of flat basis since the number of flats has increased. On this basis, between 1974 and 1980, labour costs per unit have increased by 89%. utility charges by 100% and the cost of repairs, maintenance and redecoration by 106%. The overall increase in expenditure per dwelling unit was 132% while the average increase in conservancy charges per unit was only 83%.

    In 1974, the expenditure incurred by HDB on conservancy services was $34.6 million. The income from conservancy charges was only $30.1 million. The HDB was able to absorb the deficit of $4.5 million. In 1980, expenditure rose to $148 million but income based on the old rates fixed in 1974 would have been only $55 million, resulting in a deficit of $93 million. The HDB could not continue to bear these deficits and had to raise the conservancy charges to recover part of the increased costs. To minimize hardship, the increase was implemented in two stages, namely in August 1980 and July 1981. Despite the increase in August 1980, the HDB incurred a deficit of $47 million for FY 80-81 relating to the provision of conservancy services. Even after the second stage increase in July this year, the HDB expects a deficit of $42 million for FY 81-82.

    It is obvious that the recent increases in conservancy charges are not sufficient to cover the increased conservancy expenditure by HDB. Despite this, the HDB has

Column: 300

done more to improve the upkeep of the flats and their environment. Among the major improvements to the amenities of HDB estates are the provision of additional lifts, flushing of water tanks and more frequent repairs and redecorations.

    The HDB is constantly looking for ways to keep down maintenance and conservancy costs. Some factors are beyond its control: for example, increases in utility charges and salaries of cleansing workers. The Board, however, can control the use of labour and can study ways to increase productivity. One of the most obvious ways is to mechanize cleansing and maintenance operations. Mechanization is also necessary as the HDB is facing difficulty in recruiting cleansing workers. This is partly due to the prevailing tight labour market. Besides, manual work is shunned by our young people. However, there is a limit to the mechanization of most of the cleansing operations and other jobs now performed manually. An obvious example is the sweeping of staircases. This is difficult to mechanize.

    HDB residents can play an important part in keeping down conservancy expenditure. The HDB provides a refuse chute for every flat. If residents use these conveniently located chutes to dispose of their household rubbish instead of throwing garbage out of the windows or leaving them in the corridors, the HDB will be able to reduce the number of cleansing workers deployed to sweep corridors, staircases, lift lobbies and other common areas. By making proper use of their refuse chutes and cultivating good social habits they can contribute to minimizing increases in the conservancy and maintenance costs of HDB estates.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask a supplementary question arising out of the answer? As I understand the Minister of State, the Board is not collecting enough by way of conservancy and service charges to pay for all the services provided. But I have been making a study of the Reports of the Board for the years 1979 and 1980. I may be wrong, but I find from the accounts that the Board made a

Column: 301

profit of $29,018,624 in 1979 on the conservancy and service charges collected, and in 1980 a profit of $32,899,341. Would the Minister like to comment on this?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the explanation is quite simple. The accounts do not completely reflect the situation. Some of the cost items that I have mentioned here may not have been classified or explained clearly in the accounts that the hon. Member has seen. The actual cost figures that I have reviewed and studied indicate, in fact, that there is a deficit. The figures that the hon. Member has quoted do not present a complete picture. I think the hon. Member might have been mistaken by the accounts because of the way they are presented. Unless the Member knows the full picture, it is very easy to miss out certain items.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Minister of State saying that this House cannot accept the accounts of the Board at their face value?
